settings.title: Saffron infusion
settings.description:
Serves 1 glass

Ingredients:

1 pinch of saffron (15 threads)

5 cups water 

1 cup ice cubes optional 

Make the magic happen:

In a one glass, drop one pinch of saffron. Add ice and fill container with water. Add additional fruit or herbs to garnish, if desired. Stay hydrated!

settings.title: Elevate your well-being with a pinch of gold.

settings.title: A fragrant secret ingredient
settings.description: Our premium quality saffron elevates your recipes with its strong fragrance and distinctive color. Saffron has seemingly limitless recipe applications, from hot tea to crispy tahdig.

settings.title: Premium-grade saffron
settings.content: Saffron is known to be the ‘queen of spice’ and here's how you can recognize premium quality saffron.

settings.storyContent:
“I began Moonflowers Co as a celebration of women in Afghanistan, who harvest saffron with love. Born in Kabul, Afghanistan, now in DC, I wanted to share the story of resilience of Afghan women.


The workforce in the saffron industry of Afghanistan consists of 80% women, they plant, harvest and package the saffron spice. In a country where women do not have equal opportunities and rights, and have been suffering the most from war and oppression, their livelihoods depend on the saffron industry.

Thank you for supporting Moonflowers' mission to shine light on these women and the magic of saffron. Welcome to our family.

settings.iwtContent:
Skateistan is a non-profit, founded in Kabul, Afghanistan in 2007, that empowers children through skateboarding and education in Afghanistan, Cambodia, and South Africa through a creative, arts-based education – allowing children
the opportunity to grow into leaders for a better world. They focus on groups that are excluded from sports and educational opportunities, especially girls, children with disabilities, and those from low-income households.

settings.title: What is saffron?
settings.answer: Known to be the queen of spice, saffron threads are the stigmas of the flower called Crocus Sativus or saffron crocus. Saffron is both a culinary herb and a powerful medicine, cultivated and harvested by hand.

settings.title: Where is Moonflowers saffron grown and harvested?
settings.answer: We source our saffron from our partner farms in the Herat province of Afghanistan. The family grows and harvests the saffron crocus with a lot of care, to ensure premium quality saffron stigmas.

settings.title: How do I know it’s premium quality?
settings.answer:
You can recognize the quality of saffron threads by using your own senses. Moonflowers offers the super negin saffron – which is a long stemmed, deep red, and strongly flavored saffron.  

Appearance - When you steep the threads in water, it should gradually turn into a deep, golden orange red. 

Scent - Many describe the smell of saffron as sweet, pungent, honey-like. 

Taste - While saffron smells sweet, it has a soft and velvety taste.

settings.title: What is super negin saffron?
settings.answer: Super negin saffron is Grade A+ rated saffron, known for its long stemmed, deep red, and strongly flavored saffron.

settings.title: What are the saffron types?
settings.answer:
There are four main types of saffron: sargol, super negin, negin, poshal.  

Sargol: is the type of saffron that is the very tip of the stigmas, grade 2. The Sargol saffron is known for its powerful aroma and does not contain yellow or orange threads. After the harvest and processing of the sargol saffron it contains crumbs and broken threads. 

Super Negin: is the most expensive type and rare trim of the saffron, grade 1. The super negin is known to be the most potent saffron with long deep red stigmas and no yellow or orange threads. The saffron stigmas shouldn’t contain crumbs or be cut. Super negin is considered the best in quality, color and taste. 

Negin: is known to be the longer saffron stigmas but contains some yellow and orange parts. The Negin saffron stigmas have great aroma, quality and purity, but the only difference with the super negin is that it doesn’t have the perfect color due to the portions of yellow and orange stigmas. 

Pushal: this is the cheapest and lowest quality of saffron, grade 3. The Pushal saffron contains the red saffron with a portion of the white-ish parts.The pushal saffron is produced at the beginning of the harvest season.

settings.title: How about the saffron quality grades?
settings.answer: Saffron threads are graded from I to IV, with I as the finest and IV the poorest. The crocin absorbance scale is as follows: Grade I: >190, Grade II: >150, Grade III: >110 and Grade IV: <110. The grading depends on labaratory standards set for color (crocin), flavor (safranal) and aroma (picrocrocin). The components in saffron that are tested are crocin, picrocrocin and safranal through photospectroscopy, all based on the ISO-norm 3632-2. The super negin saffron that Moonflowers offers is considered Grade A. Negin means diamond, which refers to the most valuable kind and has the highest quality. Super negin saffron contains all red stigmas only. The quality according to the ISO-norm 3632-2 should be crocin (coloring) of about 240, safranal (coloring) of about 60, and bitterness (picrocrocin) of about 95.

settings.title: What does saffron taste like?
settings.answer: The taste of saffron is very particular. It is subtle and fragrant; you recognize the scent and flavor immediately. Some describe it as pungent, earthy, honey-like.

settings.title: How do I use saffron in my recipes?
settings.answer: There are three ways to use saffron in your recipes. The easiest is to add a pinch of saffron threads to hot water and let it steep for about 30 minutes. The heat will activate the flavor and color of the saffron. If you want the saffron to completely dissolve in your recipes, you can grind it using a mortar and pestle. By adding a pinch of salt or sugar it will grind easier. If you want to preserve your saffron long-term, you can add a pinch of saffron to warm water and let it steep. Then pour the saffron water into a non-reactive ice cube tray and freeze it.

settings.title: What is the best way to store my saffron?
settings.answer: The best way to store your saffron is to place your Moonflowers tin box with saffron in a dry and cool space. Make sure that the lid is tight, to preserve the flavor and potency.

settings.title: How long does it keep after opening?
settings.answer: If you store your saffron in a dark and cool space, it will generally keep well for about 2-3 years.

settings.title: What are the health benefits of saffron?
settings.answer: Saffron is known to have an ancient history in herbal medicine. Recent studies have shown that saffron has anti-inflammatory and anti-stress properties. These properties improves your mood. Saffron is a powerful anti-oxidant as well, these are molecules that protect your cells against free redicals and oxidative stress.  Another study has proven that saffron may at as an aphrodisiac, that helps boost your libido.

settings.title: Where can I find you?
settings.answer: Click here for an overview of retailers that stock our saffron!

settings.title: How do I become a stockist for Moonflowers?
settings.answer: Email us at wholesale@moonflowers.co and we’ll set you up!

settings.title: When will my order ship?
settings.answer: All orders are shipped next day.

settings.title: Where do you ship to?
settings.answer: We ship throughout the US. If you want to have our saffron in other countries, email us at hi@moonflowers.co and we’ll make sure to get it to you.

settings.title: How much does shipping cost?
settings.answer: We offer free shipping on all orders over $50. Ground shipping is just $4.9 for any order under $50

settings.title: Is your packaging made of sustainable materials?
settings.answer: Of course! We care about the planet as much as we care about quality saffron. Our tin boxes are 100% recyclable. You can repurpose the tin boxes as well. They’re great for storing jewelry or other small items.

settings.title: How does subscriptions work?
settings.answer: Click on the saffron by weight, 2 gram/5 gram/10 gram, then click on ‘add to cart’. You will be asked to purchase as a subscription or a one-time purchase. Choose your delivery frequency, we have options of 1 month, 2 month, 3 month, or 6 month.

settings.title: How often can I get saffron delivered?
settings.answer: We offer delivery every 1 month, 2 month, 3 month or 6 month. Skip, pause or cancel anytime.

settings.title: What if I want to change the quantity frequency of my subscription?
settings.answer: Log into your Moonflowers account or create yours here. Click on ‘My Account’, then on ‘Manage Subscriptions’ under your ‘Order History’ and change the frequency up to your needs.

settings.title: Can I cancel my subscription?
settings.answer: Anytime! You can cancel your subscription by logging into your account and then select ‘Manage Subscriptions’.

settings.title: Can I gift saffron to someone?
settings.answer: Saffron makes a great gift! We know for a fact that your loved ones will love to be indulged with the saffron spice.

settings.title: How about gifting a subscription?
settings.answer: Definitely! We also have gift cards here (hyperlink) that make a great gift.

settings.title: Question that is not listed here, who do I ask?
settings.answer: Shoot as an email hi@moonflowers.co, we always answer!

settings.title: How do I stay up to date on new recipes and possible product releases?
settings.answer: Join our newsletter and we will keep you posted on all the fun stuff!

settings.title: Where did the name Moonflowers come from?
settings.answer: The saffron crocus is handpicked and starts in the very early morning hours, just before sunrise. This prevents the flowers from wilting under the sun and preserves the saffron quality. The saffron pickers work under the moonlight and this inspired us for the name Moonflowers.

settings.title: What inspired you?
settings.answer: Moonflowers was born out from the dream of helping the women of Afghanistan. Our founder, Tahmina Ghaffer, is born in Kabul, Afghanistan and is inspired by architecture, landscapes, poetry and stories from ancestors.

settings.roundheroTitles: Premium-grade saffron hand-harvested by female farmers in Herat, Afghanistan.

settings.iwtSectionTitless: Saffron is known to be the ‘queen of spice’. Use your senses to recognize premium quality saffron.

settings.siwt_title: Saffron extract has a long history in herbal medicine spanning over 2,500 years.
settings.siwt_content:
It is a powerful medicinal herb because it contains more than 150 chemical compounds, some of which can have a big impact on health. Different clinical researches have proven that saffron has multiple health benefits, such asantidepressant, boost memory, cancer prevention, heart health and PMS treatment.

* Please note these statements have not been evaluated by the Food and Drug Administration. These products are not intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any diseases.
settings.safroncta_title: Handpicked with love by women in Herat, Afghanistan

settings.sproundheroTitless: Moonflowers is proud to partner with Skateistan to donate 1% of all profits to work toward a future that is equitable for all.
settings.sproundheroContentss: Skateistan empowers children through skateboarding and education in Afghanistan, Cambodia and South Africa.
settings.spiwtContent: Skateistan is a non-profit, founded in Kabul, Afghanistan in 2007, that empowers children through skateboarding and education through a creative, arts-based education – allowing children the opportunity to grow into leaders for a better world.
settings.spiwtlContent: Their focus is on groups who are often excluded from sports and educational opportunities, especially girls, children living with disabilities and those from low-income backgrounds. Skateistan provides safe spaces where children can have fun, build their skills and confidence and break down social barriers by making new friends.

settings.fimageBox_content: Before the saffron corms can be planted, the farmers prepare the land by deep ploughing it, leveling it, removing weeds and other materials, and making small plots. Soil preparation is practiced in autumn or winter. In Afghanistan, the farmers use the ridge planting method to plant the saffron corms. This method provides better protection against high temperature as well as pest and diseases.

The saffron corms are planted generally from April through June, which leads to the best production. Saffron does not require a lot of nutrients compared to other agricultural plants. In the eastern region of Afghanistan water for the land is limited and irrigation plans are a must. Fortunately, saffron doesn’t need much irrigation. The growth of saffron starts after the first irrigation, usually around September. Water is then necessary to support the flowering of the saffron corm.

The flowering stage of the saffron starts in October and continues for three weeks. Each flower lives for only 48 hours, which is why it is key to ensure harvest within this short period of time. The saffron flowers should be picked early morning, as soon as they open. It is important for the saffron pickers to pick the flowers in a fast pace, as the wilting of the flowers makes the post-harvest process difficult. The optimal harvest time is in the very early morning, before there is full soon. This is where the name Moonflowers stems from, the best quality of saffron stigma is guaranteed when the flowers are picked under the moonlight. The saffron pickers must collect approximately 150,000 flowers to produce one kilo of saffron spice.

When the saffron flowers have been collected from the fields, they will be transported to a farm house where it’s kept in a clean and shaded facility for further processing. The ideal temperature for storage of the saffron flowers is near 0 Celsius. The quality of the saffron stigma’s relies on the immediate processing. The saffron pickers separate the stigmas from the flowers in a facility. At this stage the stigmas are bright orange-red and are attached to the flowers by pale filaments called styles. The styles as well as the yellow stamens, are worthless as spice. It takes about 450,000 stigmas to make up a kilogram of saffron spice.

The stigma must be dried to ensure premium quality. Drying must be done very precisely, if it is too moist the stigmas might get infected with fungus and when it’s too dry the stigmas might break easily into powder. In Afghanistan, the climate allows for air drying which takes up to a week.

settings.mainheroTitles: Harvested with love by women in Herat, Afghanistan
settings.banner_mainTitles: We honor all the women who, through resilience and love, plant, nourish and harvest the ancient and most precious spice.
settings.infoContent: Our saffron is sourced from a small family owned and run farm in Herat, Afghanistan. Their practice from planting the corms to harvesting is done with a lot of care, to ensure premium quality saffron stigmas.
settings.processContent1: Before the saffron corms can be planted, the farmers prepare the land by deep ploughing it, leveling it, removing weeds and other materials, and making small plots.  Soil preparation is practiced in autumn or winter. In Afghanistan, the farmers use the ridge planting method to plant the saffron corms. This method provides better protection against high temperature as well as pest and diseases. The corm is prevented from being soaked in water.
settings.processContent2: The saffron corms are planted generally from April through June, which leads to the best production. Saffron does not require a lot of nutrients compared to other agricultural plants. Saffron doesn’t need much irrigation. The growth of saffron starts after the first irrigation, usually around September. Water is then necessary to support the flowering of the saffron corm.
settings.processContent3: The flowering stage of the saffron starts in October and continues for three weeks. Each flower lives for only 48 hours, which is why it is key to ensure harvest within this short period of time. The saffron flowers should be picked early morning, as soon as they open. It is important for the saffron pickers to pick the flowers in a fast pace, as the wilting of the flowers makes the post-harvest process difficult. The optimal harvest time is in the very early morning, before there is full sun.
settings.processContent4: When the saffron flowers have been collected from the fields, they will be transported to a farm house where it’s kept in a clean and shaded facility for further processing. The ideal temperature for storage of the saffron flowers is near 0 Celcius. The quality of the saffron stigma’s relies on the immediate processing.  The saffron pickers separate the stigmas from the flowers in a facility. It takes about 450,000 stigmas to make up a kilogram of saffron spice.
settings.processContent5: The stigma must be dried to ensure premium quality.  Dehydrating of the saffron stigmas must be done very precisely, if it is too moist the stigmas might get infected with fungus and when it’s too dry the stigmas might break easily into powder. In Afghanistan, the climate allows for air drying which takes up to a week.  Electric dryers have been introduced more recently and it takes takes minutes rather than days and makes it easier to control the moisture level (12 % to 14 %) of the saffron.

settings.html: Handpicked with love under the moonlight
